contentMeta.shotlist:
UNHCR
TITLE: Syria: High Commissioner?s Aleppo visit
COUNTRY: Syria
LOCATION: Aleppo
SHOOT DATE: 01 February 2017
RELEASE DATE: 01 February 2017
SOURCE: Mazen Haffer / Warda Al Jawahiry / Edith Champagne / Wendy Tiba
LANGUAGE: English
DURATION: 01:29



SHOTLIST:

00:00 Various of Filippo Grandi, UN High Commissioner for Refugees walking around city

00:10 CLIP, Filippo Grandi, UN High Commissioner for Refugees ( English):

?Look at these ruins, the ruins of this war. This is what refugees from Syria, who are now denied entry [to the United States] have fled from.?

00:29 Various of Filippo Grandi, UN High Commissioner for Refugees walking around city

00:34 CLIP, Filippo Grandi, High Commissioner for Refugees (English):

?I think we must think first of all, that there are people here, some of them are returning to these ruins who need help, immediate help. They are cold, they are hungry, they need to work to earn some money, they need the elementary things of life in this very ancient city, all of a sudden they start again and I think we need to accelerate humanitarian assistance, we need resources for that.?

01:08 Various of destroyed buildings in the city
contentMeta.headline: HCR Syria Aleppo visit
contentMeta.dopesheet:
BACKGROUND INFORMATION:

UN High Commissioner for Refugees Filippo Grandi was in Aleppo on the third day of an official visit to Syria. He witnessed at first-hand the devastation from years of fighting. He stressed the importance of reaching a peace deal that will allow the rebuilding to begin.

RESTRICTION SUMMARY: AP CLIENTS ONLY

-- SHOTLIST:

AP TELEVISION - AP CLIENTS ONLY
Paris - 1 February 2017
1. Various of Francois Fillon at "entrepreneurial salon" event
2. Various of Marine Le Pen at event
contentMeta.headline: FR Fillon Le Pen entrepreneurs
contentMeta.dopesheet:
French presidential candidates Francois Fillon and Marine le Pen on Wednesday attended an event for entrepreneurs in the capital, Paris.
Fillon, the one-time front-runner, is slowly finding his dream of winning the Elysee Palace under water following revelations in a satirical newspaper called "Le Canard Enchaine", or "The Chained Duck".
The dirt-digging weekly's claims that Fillon's political clout helped secure handsomely paid jobs for his wife, Penelope, and two of their children have rocked the candidate's campaign.
Meanwhile, Le Pen didn't comment on reports that the European parliament has asked her to start repaying hundreds of thousands of euros it says were wrongly paid to legislative aides.
An EU parliament letter to the far-right presidential candidate published by Challenges magazine gave Tuesday as the deadline to begin repayment of about 300,000 euros (322,000 US dollars.)
In a second letter, the European parliament asks for the repayment of an additional 40,000 euros by 28 February.
The request follows the European anti-fraud office's findings that some aides were paid from the European budget while actually working as Le Pen's cabinet chief and bodyguard, breaking the parliament's rules.
contentMeta.dateline: Fillon and Le Pen mingle with entrepreneurs

RESTRICTION SUMMARY: NO ACCESS FRANCE/NO EUROVISION

 -- SHOTLIST:

BFM TV - NO ACCESS FRANCE/NO EUROVISION
Paris - 1 February 2017
1. Wide of French presidential candidate Francois Fillon with media
2. Close of Fillon surrounded by media
3. SOUNDBITE (French) Francois Fillon, French presidential candidate:
"I choose to be candidate for the presidential election. And when we decide to be candidate for the presidential election, we are not going to complain about the violence of (verbal) attacks. We accept it as part of our democratic system. And we face it. One thing I can tell you is that I will face it until the end. I will remain candidate to this presidential election. Because I?m carrying a political message, that, to me, is the only one that can help the the national recovery."
4. Fillon with media
5. Various of Fillon talking to a woman
contentMeta.headline: France Fillon 4
contentMeta.dopesheet:
French presidential candidate Francois Fillon declared on Wednesday that he would remain a candidate despite the current political scandal involving his wife and kids.
"The Canard Enchaine" newspaper published claims that Fillon not only paid his wife Penelope for an allegedly fake job as a parliamentary aide, but also employed two of the couple's children for the same positions.
The paper first published the allegations against Fillon on 25 January and then came out with a second report containing further accusations on Wednesday.
Fillon, who was France's prime minister from 2007 to 2012, has denied any wrongdoing.
contentMeta.dateline: Fillon will remain candidate despite scandal

contentMeta.shotlist:
Story number: 4078978
revision - Story: 6 / Text: 6 / Video: 6

RESTRICTION SUMMARY: AP CLIENTS ONLY

-- SHOTLIST:

AP TELEVISION - AP CLIENTS ONLY
Sao Paulo - 31 January, 2017
1. Man trying on Trump mask inside costume store
2. Close of Trump mask
3. People passing in front of them in store
4. Store manager organising Trump masks
5. SOUNDBITE (Portuguese) Pierre Sfier, manager of the "Festas e Fantasias" store:
"It's been the greatest sale, since it arrived an the start of January, it hasn't stopped selling. Since he was sworn in on Jan. 20 we've had record sales. We get 100 (masks) they go. The next day we get 200 (masks) they go. Everything we get sells."
6. Close of Trump mask
7. SOUNDBITE (Portuguese) Pierre Sfier, manager of the "Festas e Fantasias" store:
"It has sold more than (Barack) Obama, more than Dilma (Rousseff, former president of Brazil), more than the Japanese from the Federal Police (who became famous for escorting corrupt politicians and then being arrested himself for corruption). He (Trump masks) is selling more than them. He will sell a lot during carnival. (The Trump masks) Will be a great success here in Brazil."
8. Storefront
9. Various of people in store
10. Various of woman trying on Trump mask
contentMeta.headline: Brazil Trump Masks
contentMeta.dopesheet:
Masks in the likeness of United States President Donald Trump are selling out in Brazil as revellers prepare for carnival.
It is tradition in Brazil to take advantage of carnival celebrations and dress up as politicians, to either honour or mock them.
According to the store manager of a popular costume store in Sao Paulo, over 2,000 Trump masks were sold just in the month of January.
"Since he was sworn in on Jan. 20 we've had record sales," said Pierre Sfier who manages the "Festas and Fantasias" store, adding that the Trump mask has sold more than the Barack Obama and Dilma Rousseff masks.
Carnival celebrations in Brazil are officially set to start on Feb. 24.
contentMeta.dateline: Trump masks are a big hit for carnival in Brazil

contentMeta.shotlist:
Jacques Folon is a wine lover.
This evening, he enjoys an evening with a friend to savor his last glass of wine.

Jacques is 64, he drinks 14 to 20 drinks a week.
This is just below what doctors consider to be problematic use.
He never drinks alone, according to him, alcohol mainly creates A social bond.

Like many Belgians, Jacques feels that his consumption is safe.
Yet alcohol is responsible for about 200 types of ailments and especially many cancers.

Benoit is a student. He lives in a roomate situtation.
At 23, he consumes 5-7 glasses per week.
He is not a great drinker but in his room he collects special beers and strong spirits

Benoit is the only one of his friends to participate in "mineral tour."
This non-alcoholic month is going to be a real challenge.

Alexandra and Ludovic, team up as a couple for the challenge. In general, they do not drink alcohol on weekdays.

At 29 Alexandra drinks 5-7 glasses per week and Ludovic from 8 to 10 glasses.
They see this challenge as a benefit to their health

For this doctor, the initiative is positive and makes one realize what one consumes. But it is not really effective to change in habits.

All the participants we are following hope that by making their challenges public will help them stand firm.

It is true that in Belgium the solicitations are numerous. Belgians are the most alcohol consumers in Europe.

SOT 1: Jacques Folon - ICHEC professor
SOT 2: Beno?t Pitsaer - Student
SOT 3: Alexandra Mertens - Employee
SOT 4: Thomas Orban - Doctor

============================================================================
ORIGINAL FRENCH SCRIPT

Jacques Folon est un amateur de vin.
Ce soir, il profite d'une soir?e avec une amie pour savourer son dernier verre de vin.

Jacques a 64 ans, il boit de 14 ? 20 verres par semaine.
C'est juste en dessous de ce que les m?decins consid?rent comme une consommation probl?matique.
Il ne boit jamais seul, selon lui, l'alcool cr?e surtout du lien social.

Comme de nombreux belges, Jacques estime que sa consommation est sans risque.
Pourtant l'alcool est responsable d'environ 200 types d'affections et notamment de nombreux cancers.

Benoit lui est ?tudiant. Il vit en collocation.
A 23 ans, il consomme 5-7 verres par semaine.
Ce n'est pas un grand buveur mais dans sa chambre, il collectionne bi?res sp?ciales et alcools forts

Benoit est le seul de ses amis ? participer ? "tourn?e min?rale."
Ce mois sans alcool va ?tre un vrai d?fi.

Alexandra et Ludovic, font ?quipe en couple pour le d?fi. En g?n?ral, ils ne boivent pas d'alcool en semaine sauf exception.

A 29 ans Alexandra boit de 5-7 verres par semaine et Ludovic de 8 ? 10 verres.
Ce challenge, ils le voient comme un b?n?fice pour leur sant?

Pour ce m?decin, l'initiative est positive pour r?aliser ce que l'on consomme. Mais pas r?ellement efficace changer ses habitudes.

Tous les participants que nous suivons esp?rent que le fait de rendre public leur d?fi les aidera ? tenir bon.

Il est vrai qu'en Belgique les sollicitations sont nombreuses. Les belges sont m?mes les plus consommateurs d'alcool en Europe.

SOT 1 : Jacques Folon ? ICHEC professor
SOT 2 : Beno?t Pitsaer ? Student
SOT 3 : Alexandra Mertens ? Employee
SOT 4 : Thomas Orban - Doctor
contentMeta.headline: BE No alcohol month
contentMeta.dopesheet:
The site already has over 90,000 registered members. We decided to follow 4 challengers. We will find them in 15 days and in a month to take stock. Aline Delvoye met them last night with some last drink.

========================================================================

ORIGINAL FRENCH SCRIPT

Le site compte d?j? plus de 90.000 inscrits. Nous avons d?cid? de suivre 4 challengeurs. Nous les retrouverons dans 15 jours et dans un mois pour faire le bilan. Aline Delvoye les a rencontr?s hier soir en compagnie parfois d'un dernier verre.
contentMeta.dateline: Mineral tour: it is the campaign without alcohol launched by the foundation against Cancer. It proposes to register everyone to realize a challenge: to pass the month of February without drinking a drop of alcohol.

contentMeta.shotlist:
SOT (English) Dr Ian Clarke, Zika Incident Manager- filmed at WHO HQ, Geneva, Switzerland on 01 Feb 2017:

"Today marks one year since the Declaration of the Public Health Emergency of International Concern for Zika virus.

The Director-General met with an independent panel of 18 experts and based on their advice, the decision was to declare this a Public Health Emergency of International Concern.

But really the important aspects there were at the time, we really didn?t know enough about what was causing these cases of both Guillain- Barr? syndrome, but also microcephaly, in at the time it was Brazil.

There was suspicion that it could be linked to Zika, but we didn?t have that information, and of course we were faced with this ongoing, fairly large scale outbreaks of Zika, not just in Brazil, but starting to move to other countries.

So this really made it an extraordinary event, which was one of the key criteria that was using in making that declaration at the time.

So the Public Health Emergency of International Concern, the declaration, was extremely important in galvanizing and collaborating this effort across the world.

It enabled WHO to very quickly put together a strategy, based on prevention, detection, care and management and research and then to reach out to the partners, over 60 partners, in really helping to deliver against that.

In terms of research, a lot of progress has been made since the Declaration of the Public Health Emergency of International Concern, we have done a lot of work around moving forward the vaccine development, we have over 40 candidate vaccines, that we were able to fast-track using the WHO R&D Blueprint, and of course this will take time, potentially another three or four years until those are ready, but good progress has been made around that as well.

We now understand that Zika virus is a cause of microcephaly and other complications, and in fact we know that these complications go beyond microcephaly. We are starting to understand the broader scope of Zika congenital syndrome.

In terms of progress on prevention, we have now much stronger elements around vector control, in terms of controlling the mosquitos that carry the Zika virus.

The importance now is to really help to maintain and coalesce that momentum into a much longer term programme of work.

Managing the initial response through an incident management, through an emergency response, was exactly the right thing to do.

In the longer term we now need to embed this into the real core programmes of WHO much the way we manage other infectious diseases, chikungunya, yellow fever, dengue."


++ NO SHOTLIST PROVIDED FOR THE BRAZIL MATERIAL PART+++
contentMeta.headline: Zika report  one year
contentMeta.dopesheet:
Soundbites - Dr Ian Clarke, Zika Incident Manager (filmed at WHO HQ, Geneva, Switzerland - 01 Feb 2017)

Today marks one year since the Declaration of the Public Health Emergency of International Concern for Zika virus.

The Director-General met with an independent panel of 18 experts and based on their advice, the decision was to declare this a Public Health Emergency of International Concern.

But really the important aspects there were at the time, we really didn?t know enough about what was causing these cases of both Guillain- Barr? syndrome, but also microcephaly, in at the time it was Brazil.

There was suspicion that it could be linked to Zika, but we didn?t have that information, and of course we were faced with this ongoing, fairly large scale outbreaks of Zika, not just in Brazil, but starting to move to other countries.

So this really made it an extraordinary event, which was one of the key criteria that was using in making that declaration at the time.

So the Public Health Emergency of International Concern, the declaration, was extremely important in galvanizing and collaborating this effort across the world.

It enabled WHO to very quickly put together a strategy, based on prevention, detection, care and management and research and then to reach out to the partners, over 60 partners, in really helping to deliver against that.

In terms of research, a lot of progress has been made since the Declaration of the Public Health Emergency of International Concern, we have done a lot of work around moving forward the vaccine development, we have over 40 candidate vaccines, that we were able to fast-track using the WHO R&D Blueprint, and of course this will take time, potentially another three or four years until those are ready, but good progress has been made around that as well.

We now understand that Zika virus is a cause of microcephaly and other complications, and in fact we know that these complications go beyond microcephaly. We are starting to understand the broader scope of Zika congenital syndrome.

In terms of progress on prevention, we have now much stronger elements around vector control, in terms of controlling the mosquitos that carry the Zika virus.

The importance now is to really help to maintain and coalesce that momentum into a much longer term programme of work.

Managing the initial response through an incident management, through an emergency response, was exactly the right thing to do.

In the longer term we now need to embed this into the real core programmes of WHO much the way we manage other infectious diseases, chikungunya, yellow fever, dengue.
contentMeta.dateline: Zika one year after the declaration of Emergency of International Concern.

contentMeta.shotlist: -Video of Lars Lagerb?ck arriving for the federation press conference, on Ullevaal Stadium in Oslo.
contentMeta.headline: Norway coach Lagerback
contentMeta.dopesheet:
Lars Lagerb?ck presented as Norway's new men's national team head coach

He was presented at noon today. Surprise, as he was believed to have retired from head coaching.

contentMeta.headline: UN SG reax Trump refugee ban
contentMeta.dopesheet: United Nations Secretary-General Ant?nio Guterres expressed concern at decisions made by Trump administration regarding refugee ban. The secretary general noted that, refugees fleeing conflict are entitled to be treated according to international refugee law. Stating that countries have the right and the obligation, to responsibly manage their borders to avoid infiltration by members of terrorist organizations, Mr. Guterres cautioned that this cannot be based on any form of discrimination related to religion, ethnicity or nationality, noting that doing so can be ineffective to protect countries from terror threat. He warned that it could ?trigger widespread anxiety and anger that may facilitate the propaganda of the very terrorist organizations we all want to fight against?. Asked about possible withdrawal of US funding from the United Nations, Antonio Guterres responded that he didn?t want to spend too much time talking about things, which might happen, so no to bring them to reality. The secretary general did not wholeheartedly endorse the idea of ?safe zones? for refugees in Syria. He reminded of Srebrenica, where 1995 massacre of more than 8,000 Muslim Bosniaks took place despite the area being designated as s a ?safe zone?.
contentMeta.dateline: UN Secretary General calls US travel ban ineffective in fighting terror and in violation of UN principals

Trump walks in, shakes hands with people, they sit down

SOUNDBITE (English) Donald Trump, President of the United States of America: ?Yes, if we end up with the same gridlock that they?ve had in Washington that has lasted longer than eight years, in fairness to President Obama, a lot longer than eight years, but if we end up with that gridlock I would say, if you can Mitch, go nuclear. Because that would be an absolute shame if a man of this quality was caught up in the web. So I would say, it?s up to Mitch, but I would say go for it.?

The meeting continues as press leaves
contentMeta.headline: Trump Scotus nuclear option
contentMeta.dopesheet: President Trump is meeting different interest groups - including the gun lobby - to discuss his Supreme Court pick. Wayne LaPierre of the National Rifle Association was one of those sitting at the table, along with evangelical groups. They all seem to be pleased by Trump's choice of conservative judge Neil Gorsuch to fill the vacant seat on the court. The President also urged the Senate Majority Leader to use the 'nuclear option' to overcome a potential blocking of the nomination by Democrats. That would see Senate rules change to stop a filibuster of Supreme Court justices, needing only 51 votes to approve them rather than 60 to overcome the filibuster.
contentMeta.dateline: President Trump meets different interest groups - including the National Rifle Association - to discuss his Supreme Court pick.

contentMeta.shotlist:
1 ? SOT, Philippe Lamberts ?  ? Green group ? MEP (FRENCH) : ?Things reproached to Ms Le Pen are quite simple : as MEPs, we all have the right to employ some people, some parliamentary assistants. Some of them work in our districts, in France for Marine Le Pen for example. Others are working as accredited assistants, they?re paid on an European rate, with the European social security, and they have to work in this building : they must be based in Brussels, they must work in Brussels? HQs, for the parliamentary work of the deputy?. They must work on legislation, or on parliamentary resolutions? But apparently, Marine Le Pen?s ex sister-in-law never worked here! She was paid as and she was officially an accredited assistant, but in fact, she has never worked here, in the European Parliament. These facts have been proved, an investigation was launched by the European anti-fraud office (OLAF), and this office has stated that this accredited assistant was in fact a fictitious one. And she wasn?t working for the European Parliament?. 
2 ? SOT, Philippe Lamberts ?  ? Green group ? MEP (FRENCH) : ?We?re talking here about a very particular politician. A politician who has launched a crusade against European institutions, with a lot of success. She usually denounces the abuses on an European level, and I can understand that some of us say : ?If she want to denounce abuses, she?d better keep her own house in order?.
3 ? SOT, Marc Tarabella ? ?Socialist Group? MEP (FRENCH) : ?This is the problem, with Ms Le Pen?s reaction : she?s always the victim of the system. But enough with victimization ! Because, and it?s really simple, the investigation has shown that her bodyguard was paid with the European Parliament?s fund but never came here, in Brussels. Her assistants were clearly working for the National Front. And clearly, she doesn?t work a lot in the European Parliament during the commissions. Politics didn?t judge politics ! The investigation was launched by the European anti-fraud office, also named OLAF, and Marine Le Pen was heard several times, and apparently she wasn?t convincing when she talked about her assistants??.
4 ? Wide panning shot of European Parliament.
5 ? MS of Philippe Lamberts speaking. 
6 ? CS of Lamberts? hands.
7 ? MS of lamberts speaking. 
8 ? CS of Lamberts speaking. 
9 ? Wide panning shot of journalist and deputy speaking in front of the European Parliament. 
10 ? Mid panning shot of Marc Tarabella. 
11 ? Various of European parliament (exterior shots).
contentMeta.headline: BE Le Pen reax
contentMeta.dopesheet: France's far-right candidate for president, Marine Le Pen, refuses to repay nearly 300,000 euros of EU funds an European investigation says she misspent

contentMeta.shotlist:
SOT (English) George Osborne, Former Chancellor:
"In the media and in newspapers the truth is that while Britain is seeking the maximum possible access to the single market for goods and for services and while we hope that the fact we have a trade deficit and a very important financial centre will count in our favour. The government has chosen and I respect this decision not to make the economy the priority in this negotiation they have prioritised immigration control and that was a clear message from the referendum campaign and they've also prioritise removing European Court of Justice jurisdiction from the United Kingdom and in that sense asserting parliamentary sovereignty although I would point out that parliament can choose to leave the EU as indeed we are choosing to do in the coming days. So we're not prioritising the economy although we hope for the best possible arrangement the European Union is not prioritising economy either in these negotiations having spent the last couple of weeks in Berlin and in Paris talking some of the French and German political leaders it is absolutely clear that while they understand that Britain is very important market for their businesses their priority is to maintain the integrity of the remaining twenty seven members of the European Union."

Yvette Cooper - Labour Party

Tim Farron - Liberal Democrats
contentMeta.headline: Uk Brexit Article 50 Vote
contentMeta.dopesheet: After two days of debate in the Commons, they're expected to approve what's called ARTICLE FIFTY ... triggering a two-year negotiation before the U-K leaves.
contentMeta.dateline: Mps speak in Parliament before vote.

contentMeta.shotlist: various of people with mobile phones
contentMeta.headline: PL SIM cards registered
contentMeta.dopesheet: Ferbuary 1 is the last day that pre-paid SIM cards used in Poland can be registered under new rules designed to combat terrorism. The following day, unregistered cards will be turned off. The new rules came into force under an anti-terrorism law adopted by parliament last year. The aim is to make it more difficult for criminals, including anyone involved in terrorist activities, to remain anonymous .However, Polish media reported that criminals would still be able to buy SIM cards. One method is to buy a pre-paid card from a country that does not require registration.
contentMeta.dateline: Ferbuary 1  is the last day that pre-paid SIM cards used in Poland can be registered .New rules aim to fight terror

contentMeta.headline: UEFA Referee Winter Courses
contentMeta.dopesheet:
A total of 128 male and female referees from Europe are attending UEFA?s winter referee courses from 29 January to 2 February in Malaga, Spain. The gathering is split into two parts; one for elite referees, and an introductory course for newcomers to the FIFA international list.

The courses entail training sessions and fitness checks, visual tests and body fat measuring, instruction sessions, group discussions and feedback meetings, which are led by the former international referees that comprise UEFA?s Referees Committee, including UEFA chief refereeing officer, Pierluigi Collina.

contentMeta.shotlist:
1. Wide shot of mosque interior
2. Bullet hole in the window
3. Blood stain on the carpet
4. Ahmed Elrefai, Quebec mosque administrator SOT (English): So, the gunman came from that entry. This is the entrance to the mosque and started shooting, two people on the outside at the entrance and then he came in and started shooting people here. Then he entered and started killing people on that corner behind the pillar. This is the crime scene in general
5. Ahmed Elrefai, Quebec mosque administrator SOT (English): This is very emotional for me. I cannot describe that. These are my friends, my brothers, who have been killed here.
6. Ahmed Elrefai, Quebec mosque administrator SOT (English): This would be the hardest time to have to open and start praying again in this scene. We are planning to renovate everything, change the colors, change the painting, change everything, just to take these memories out of our heads.
7. Ahmed Elrefai, Quebec mosque administrator SOT (English): First of all we are all Canadians, we all live in Quebec, we are all Quebecois, we are going to stay here. We are one society, one community. Yes, we are different, different religion, different in faith, but we are all Canadians.
8. Blood stain on the carpet
9. Bullet hole in the window
10. Blood stains on the floor
11. Bullet holes in the wall
12. Blood stains on the wall
13. Bullet holes in the wall
14. Mosque exterior
contentMeta.headline: CA Mosque interiors
contentMeta.dopesheet: Ahmed Elrefai, Quebec mosque administrator, gave a tour for the media on the scene of the terrorist attack, which took place on January 29th. Six people were dead and eight wounded. The mosque is now closed. The congregation expect to resume praying in the building after renovations.
contentMeta.dateline: Quebec mosque administrator gives media a tour of the terrorist attack scene

contentMeta.headline: Empire State Building run up
contentMeta.dopesheet: The race has been held annually since 1978 and involves runners from around the world racing up the 1,575 stairs of the skyscraper, starting from the lobby and racing up to the 86th floor.
contentMeta.dateline: The annual Empire State Building Run-Up is to be held in Manhattan, New York.

contentMeta.headline: FR Fillon Penelope rally
contentMeta.dopesheet:
French presidential candidate Francois Fillon, speaking in front of entrepreneurs, declared on Wednesday that he would remain a candidate despite the current political scandal involving his wife and kids.

"The Canard Enchaine" newspaper published claims that Fillon not only paid his wife Penelope for an allegedly fake job as a parliamentary aide, but also employed two of the couple's children for the same positions.
contentMeta.dateline: Penelopegate: Fillon will remain candidate despite scandal
